data.text: Contents
Introduction

The i‑STAT Alinity instrument is an analytical, in vitro diagnostic device which can analyse a range of tests including blood gas, lactate, glucose, sodium, potassium, urea and creatinine. The design enables it to be taken to the patient's bedside (point of care) or a convenient location near the point of care. The instrument requires i‑ STAT single-use cartridges containing sensors to perform quantitative diagnostic testing on whole blood. After the insertion of a filled test cartridge, the instrument carefully monitors and controls the testing process. The only user intervention is in the form of data entry. Data entry is performed via the touchscreen or by barcode capture. Throughout the cycle, the instrument performs a series of quality checks. These checks are designed to monitor the status of the instrument and the quality of the cartridge. The instrument and cartridge together allow the user to perform clinical testing and administrative tasks related to in vitro quantification of various analytes in a whole blood sample.

The specimen is inserted into the sample well, filling the sample chamber; the volume and placement of the specimen are monitored by the analyser itself. Use of the Snap Closure creates an air-tight seal necessary for proper fluid movement within the cartridge. The closure also ensures that the calibrant (if applicable) and sample remain contained within the cartridge during the testing cycle and subsequential disposal.

The sensor channel then directs the specimen from the sample chamber to the sensors. An extension of this channel becomes a waste chamber to receive the calibrant solution (if applicable) as it is displaced by the sample.
In CHEM8+, GC3+ and CG4+ cartridges, an air chamber is located between the calibrant solution (if applicable) and the sample to prevent the two from mixing.
The size of this air segment is monitored by the analyser.

The sensors are electrodes micro fabricated on silicon chips. Electrodes have chemically sensitive coatings such as ion-selective membranes and enzyme layers. In cartridges that perform coagulation tests, reagents, such as clot activators, are coated on the plastic above the sensors. Each sensor is connected to a contact pad by a signal line.

An air vent on the underside of the cartridge, beyond the fluid front, allows the calibrant and the sample to flow forward, but not out of the cartridge. The sensors respond to the calibrant solution, if applicable, and the sample by producing measurable signals related to analyte concentration. The contact pads conduct the signals generated by the sensors to the analyser. In order to function properly, must be exercised not to contaminate the contact pads during cartridge handling.
A waste chamber (beneath the cartridge label) holds calibrant fluid after it has been used.
All i-STAT cartridges require thermal control at 37 °C, and include heating elements on the underside of the sensor chips which are contacted and heated by the instrument's thermal probes.
LED:  Indicates  status  of  the instrument.
GREEN:  Instrument  is  starting up or test results are complete. WHITE: Cartridge is processing. RED:  Requires  immediate attention.
BLUE: Battery is charging. Yellow: Instrument is printing.
Display Screen
POWER  BUTTON:  Press  and hold for 2 seconds to power up or power down the instrument.
BARCODE  CAPTURE BUTTON:  Press  and  hold  to capture  a  barcode.  Audible tones  indicate  successful  and unseuccessful barcode captures
CARTRIDGE  PORT:  Cartridge or  Electronic  Simulator  is inserted into the cartridge port to initiate testing.

CAMERA  AND  IR  PORT: Camera is activated by pressing and holding the barcode capture button.  The  display  screen displays  the  object  within  the cameras  view.  The  IR  port sends  information  from  the instrument  to  the  portable printer.
BATTERY:  Rechargeable battery is the sole power source for the instrument.
Scope

Point of Care Testing (POCT) is an established part of clinical practice, offering in many instances, rapid and convenient provision of test results that can be of benefit to the patient. It is however, a significant risk management issue for the Trust. Results obtained by non-specialist staff carry as much weight in patient management as results from sophisticated equipment in the care of professional staff. Incorrect results have the same health and legal implications, whatever their origin.

This SOP is for all staff required to use the i-Stat Alinity instrument. The purpose of this document is to ensure reliable performance and management of the risks associated with testing outside the main laboratory. This procedure describes correct use of the POCT equipment in order to minimise risk to both patient and user, and ensure consistent procedures are in place throughout the Trust.

Individuals who have not been trained and competency assessed in the use of the Abbott i-Stat are not authorised to use this device. This document has not been written as a substitute for practical training and competency.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Point of Care Testing Committee
The POCT committee is responsible for overseeing and co-ordinating all aspects of the POCT service within their Trust. Clinical Governance for POCT services is
provided through the POCT policy. This policy is reviewed and updated every 2 years.
POCT Operational Team

This team comprises of relevant personnel from Pathology First. Teams should be adequately resourced to enable them to implement and monitor compliance with the POCT policy and procedure. They are responsible for ensuring any recommendations imposed on the service by the committee are carried out.
Chief Executive

As the accountable officer, has overall responsibility for ensuring the Trust has robust, complete, and up to date procedures in place to govern and guide activities so that legal, and national requirements are met.
Pathology Clinical Director
Holds the ultimate responsibility for Point of Care Testing as guardian of Clinical Governance.
Advises and arbitrates if necessary if agreement about the introduction of a POCT service cannot be reached.
Ensures guidelines are in place for interpretation of results and further patient management.
Clinical Lead for POCT
Has clinical oversight for Point of Care Testing, liaising between the Trust and Pathology First on matters including current testing protocols and implementation of new equipment/ tests.
Holds the role of Chairperson of the Point of Care Testing Committee.
Reviews POCT EQA and reports upon it.
Deputy Director of Nursing, Associate Director of Nursing and Matrons
Heads of Nursing and Midwifery and Matrons have a responsibility to ensure correct procedures are followed.
Ward or Departmental Managers
To take on managerial ownership of any POCT equipment within their area and to ensure that it is maintained and used correctly.
They will ensure the competency of all users of POCT in their area. They will keep records of initial training, competency statements and update training.

If appropriate they will appoint a link person to oversee the day-to-day operation of POCT equipment within their area. The use of a Link Person does not absolve the ward/department manager of full responsibility for POCT

Where there has been an incident involving POCT devices, including inadequate performance or documentation of patient or Quality Assurance results, Ward or Departmental managers will investigate the incident and be responsible for reporting this to POCT. All such incidents should be brought to the attention of the POCT manager and the POCT committee.
Any request for new, upgraded or replacement POCT processes must be submitted to the POCT committee for approval. This includes free, trial and loan
devices.
Point of Care Testing Link Person

A Link Person may be designated within a ward/department for the purpose of ensuring the day to day operation of POCT systems, ensuring equipment is functioning and necessary consumables are available. They may provide cascade training, having been trained to a high level of competence, ensuring staff undertaking POCT are suitable to do so.
Pharmacy
Pharmacy is responsible for standardising, ordering and supplying the majority of POCT consumables as directed by the POCT committee.
POCT Operations Manager and Team Manager

The POCT service managers monitor the POCT service within each Trust. They ensure that POCT policies and procedures are adhered to and that adequate resources and support from Pathology First are available to facilitate a safe and reliable service.
Clinicians
The responsibility for patient results obtained using POCT and therapeutic decisions based on those results lies with the requesting clinician for the ward/department.
All Users

The individual conducting the analysis is accountable for the results they generate using POCT devices. They must ensure their POCT training is up to date and that their competence is maintained. It is the responsibility of the user:

To follow procedures as set out in the documented Standard Operating Procedure, including sample taking and handling, instrument checks and/or Quality Control, recording of results and disposal of consumables.
To undertake and record External Quality Control analysis as required.

To report suspect Quality Control results or possible instrument malfunction immediately to the Link person or person in charge at the time and to stop using the equipment until the matter has been resolved.
To report abnormal or suspect patient results to the responsible person immediately
To report adverse incidents related to POCT devices on Datix, to the Link nurse where used and to the POCT team.
Instructions for use
Health and safety/ COSHH
Users must make use of personal protective equipment (PPE) when handling patient samples according to Infection Control Standard Precautions.
Waste must be disposed of according to handling of healthcare waste policy
and procedures.
The device should be cleaned with Clinell universal sanitising wipes. A decontamination certificate may be issued before servicing and repair as required.
Equipment and special supplies  This procedure requires:
i-Stat Alinity instrument
i-Stat Alinity base station
i-Stat Alinity rechargeable battery
i-Stat Cartridges
i-Stat Alinity Printer
i-Stat Alinity Electronic Stimulator
i-Stat Tricontrols control solution
Heparinised blood gas syringe
Gloves
Clinell swab
Sharps bin
Reagents, calibrations and quality control materials
5.3.1 Reagents
The i-Stat cartridge storage is between 2 and 8°C if kept refrigerated or  and 30°C if kept at room temperature. The cartridges must not be exposed to temperatures exceeding 30°C.

The cartridges must not be used beyond the expiry date printed on the individual pouches and box. Refer to room temperature or refrigeration temperature expiry dates according to how the cartridges are to be stored.
A cartridge must be used immediately after it is removed from its pouch.

A cartridge taken from refrigerated storage must stand in its pouch at room temperature for 5 minutes before use, or a box of pouched cartridges must stand at room temperature for one hour before use. Do not return cartridges to the refrigerator if they have been brought to room temperature.
Do not use a cartridge if the pouch appears damaged.
5.3.2 Calibrations
No calibration materials required as the instrument carries out its own internal calibration check upon insertion of a test cartridge.
5.3.3 Quality control
Daily electronic simulator test

The Electronic Simulator is a quality control device used to evaluate the i‑Stat Alinity instrument's ability to read the electronic signal from a cartridge. When inserted into an i‑Stat Alinity instrument, the Electronic Simulator initiates a series of self-checks which verify the electronic and thermal functionality used with all cartridge types. This must be carried out daily by ward staff.
Weekly liquid i-stat tricontrol controls

This must be carried out weekly by ward staff according to the schedule set up on the analyser. These controls must be kept refrigerated between 2 and 8°C until the expiry date printed on the pouch or control ampoule. If PO2 is to be measured, equilibrate the ampoule at room temperature for 4 hours before use. If not, equilibrate the ampoule for approximately  minutes at room (ambient) temperature. An unopened ampoule of control solution may be kept at room temperature for 5 days.
The barcode on the Tricontrol must be scanned before opening the ampoule.
i‑Stat TriControls ampoule testing must be performed immediately upon opening when testing pH, PCO2, PO2 or iCa.
i-Stat TriControls ampoule testing must be performed within 10 minutes of opening the ampoule when testing all other available parameters.
External quality assurance (EQA)

The Point of Care Testing Team obtain WEQAS External Quality Assurance (EQA) samples monthly. They will run these samples as if they are patient samples according to 5.4.3. Instructions for Use: Procedure for analysing patient samples.
Instructions for use
5.4.1 Procedure for performing the electronic stimulator test

Verify the performance of the analyser by using the Electronic Simulator (internal or external) on the days that the analyser is in use as a means of internal daily control check. The Electronic Simulator may also be used in the event of Troubleshooting. To perform an Electronic Simulator check:
5.4.2 The procedure for running weekly liquid QCs
Transferring the control solution: syringe with blunt tip needle
Plain syringes (1cc or 3cc sterile syringes with blunt tip needles) are recommended to transfer aqueous control solutions from the ampoule to the cartridge.
To use a syringe:
If air is trapped between the leading edge of the solution and the plunger, do not invert the syringe to expel it; this will not affect solution near the tip of the syringe.
If air bubbles are continually drawn into the syringe, or if a bubble is trapped near the tip of the syringe, discard the ampoule and syringe.

Note: Since aqueous based solutions such as controls lack the buffering capabilities of whole blood, the transfer process from  ampoule to cartridge must be  more expedient than with a patient sample.
If weekly QCs fail, perform them again. Should they fail a second time, DO NOT use the analyser, remove from area and escalate to the POCT team. Never use the i-Stat in the event of IQC failure.
5.4.3 Procedure for analysing patient samples
Recording and interpreting patient results
5.5.1 Printing results
5.5.2 Reference range
Training requirements

The test should only be carried out by a member of staff who has been trained and competency assessed. Each staff member takes responsibility for ensuring the quality of all monitoring carried out by him/her. The staff member must ensure their i-Stat Alinity training is updated and that their competence to perform tests on this instrument is maintained. Practical training and competence assessment is available via the Trust POCT team.
Monitoring and audit

All Clinical Unit managers are responsible for monitoring the i-Stat instruments in their  area. They must ensure that the standard operating procedure is followed on a day to day basis. The POCT team will perform audit on the use of the i-Stat instruments and report their findings to the appropriate Clinical Unit Manager, Matron and governance leads. A copy will also be sent to the Director of Nursing, Infection control, Risk and Litigation and the POCT committee.

data.text: Approval and implementation

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the POCT Committee and Pathology Clinical Governance Committee which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document Control team for submission and ratification by
the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the POCT Committee and Pathology Clinical Governance Committee of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.
Equality impact assessment
The Trust is committed to the provision of a service that is fair, accessible and
meets the needs of all individuals. (Refer to appendix 1)
References
Abbott i-Stat Alinity Systems Operations Manual
The Medicines and Healthcare Products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), Management
and use of IVD Point of Care Testing Devices, DB2002 (03), Revised January 2021. United Kingdom Accreditation Service, www.ukas.com
The Royal College of pathologists. The Retention and Storage of Pathological Records and Archives. (5th Edition 2015) www.rcpath.org
